document.masterDocTitle: The larva of Plectrocnemia renetta Malicky 1975 (Trichoptera, Polycentropodidae), including a discriminatory matrix to the larvae of Plectrocnemia Stephens 1836 species of Greece

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The larva of Plectrocnemia renetta Malicky 1975 (Trichoptera, Polycentropodidae), including a discriminatory matrix to the larvae of Plectrocnemia Stephens 1836 species of Greece

heading.emphasis:
Description of the 5th instar larva of
Plectrocnemia renetta

subSubSection.paragraph: Biometry. Body length of 5th instar larvae ranging from 25.5 to 28.9 mm, head width from 2.32 to 2.57 mm (n = 3).

Head. Head capsule prognathous, surface smooth, slightly elongated in shape, posterior third tapering ( Figs. 1, 2 ). Coloration yellowish brown, with dark brown muscle attachment spots on frontoclypeus and parietalia ( Figs. 1, 2 ). Large pale ring present around eyes ( Fig. 3 ). Head capsule with complete set of primary setae (most of them visible in Fig. 1 and numbered). Frontoclypeus bell-shaped, with deep central constriction posterior of eye level; its posterior spots arranged in a half-trapezoidal pattern ( Fig. 1 , dotted line). Antennae very small, near anterior parietal border and frontoclypeal suture, consisting of pale tubercle with four pale, tiny apical setae (not visible in Fig. 1 ). Anteclypeus light brown, with three white longitudinal stripes ( Fig. 4 ). Labrum sclerotized, whitish to pale yellow, with narrow dark anterior border and distinct posterior mark ( Fig. 4 , arrow); with complete set of 6 primary setae per side. Anterior ventral apotome medium brown, very narrow, with elongated lateral lobes ( Fig. 2 a ); submental sclerite medium brown, trapezoidal ( Fig. 2 ss); maxillary lobe and palp light to medium brown ( Fig. 2 ml, mp); labial spinneret short, not extending anterior of head margin, with labial palps appressed to its sides ( Fig. 2 ls). Yellowish-brown mandibles with black cutting edges and teeth. Each mandible consisting of dorsal and ventral blade along mesal margin and one apical tooth ( Figs. 5 a, 6 a ); each ventral and dorsal blade with 3 subapical teeth along its edge except right upper blade with only 1 large subapical tooth and 1 tiny subapical tooth very close to large one ( Figs. 5, 6 , arrows). Small group of setae in central concavity of left mandible (not visible in Figs. 5, 6 ), but lacking in right mandible.

Thorax. Pronotum sclerotized, tapering posteriorly; pronotal sclerite pale yellow to yellowish brown, with medium brown muscle attachment spots ( Figs. 1, 3 ). As common in Polycentropodidae , posterior pronotal corners prolonged ventrally in long pointed processus ventrales almost meeting at midline ( Fig. 2 , arrows). Posterior and posterolateral margins of pronotum thickened and darkly striped; anterior end of dark stripe touching pleural suture ( Fig. 3 ); anterior border with widely spaced, continuous row of straight setae ( Fig. 1 ), with 18–22 setae of varying lengths distributed along border of each pronotal half. Prosternal horn lacking, as in other Polycentropodidae .

Mesonotum and metanotum completely membranous, with purplish hue dorsally and whitish coloration laterally and ventrally. Meso- and metathoraces with one pair of short anterodorsal setae ( Fig. 7 ad), one pair of long posterodorsal setae ( Fig. 7 pd) and one short and one long pleural setae ( Fig. 7 pl). Foretrochantin (
Figs. 3 t
,
8 t
) yellowish brown, elongate, digitiform and acute, fused with yellowish brown episternum ( Figs. 3 , 8 s ) without suture; with black pleural suture between episternum and epimeron (
Figs. 3
, 8 m ), the latter posteriorly elongated, acute and strongly bent ventrad (
Fig. 2 m
). Mid- and hind pleural sclerites ( Fig. 10 mp) much smaller, elongate triangular, with blackish ventral margins.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–6 .
Plectrocnemia renetta Malicky 1975
, 5th instar larva. 1, head and prothorax, dorsal (dotted lines = halftrapezoidal pattern of spots on posterior frontoclypeus, about 100°; small numerals refer to setal positions); 2, head and prosternum, ventral (a = anterior ventral apotome; ls – labial spinneret; ml = maxillary lobe; mp = maxillary palp; m = ventral process of epimeron; ss = submental sclerite; arrows = ventral processes of pronotum); 3, head and prothorax, right lateral (m = epimeron; s = episternum; t = foretrochantin); 4, labrum, dorsal (arrow = central pigmented mark); 5, mandibles, dorsal (a = apical tooth; arrows = subapical teeth); 6, mandibles, ventral (a = apical tooth; arrows = subapical teeth). Scale bars: 0.5 mm.

FIGURES 7–11 .
Plectrocnemia renetta Malicky 1975
, 5th instar larva. 7, metathorax, right lateral (ad = anterodorsal seta ( sa 1); mp = metapleuron; pd = posterodorsal seta ( sa 2); pl = pleural seta ( sa 3)); 8, left foreleg, posterior (m = epimeron; s = episternum; t = foretrochantin; double arrow = projected half length of tibia); 9, right midleg, anterior; 10, right hind leg, anterior (mp = metapleuron; arrows = apical spurs on tibia); 11, abdominal segment V, right lateral (ad = anterodorsal seta ( sa 1); pd = posterodorsal seta ( sa 2); pl = pleural seta ( sa 3); v = ventral seta; dotted oval = lateral fringe). Scale bars: 0.5 mm.

FIGURES 12–17 . Figures 12–14 .
Plectrocnemia renetta Malicky 1975
, 5th instar larva: 12, abdominal segment IX, ventral (ip = innermost primary seta; op = outermost primary seta; p = intermediate primary setae); 13, abdominal segment IX, dorsal, posterolateral setal trio (is = inner secondary seta; os = outer secondary seta; p = primary seta); 14, left anal proleg, left lateral (sc = distal sclerotized section; so = proximal unsclerotized section; dotted lines = right angle superimposed on obtuse-angled anal claw). Figure 15.
P. kingi McLachlan 1881
, 5th instar larva, left foreleg, posterior (double arrow = projected half length of tibia). Figure 16. P. g.
geniculata McLachlan 1871
, 5th instar larva, abdominal segment IX, ventral (ip = innermost primary seta; op = outermost primary seta; p = intermediate primary setae). Figure 17. P. c.
conspersa (Curtis 1834)
, 5th instar larva, abdominal segment IX, ventral (ip = innermost primary seta; op = outermost primary seta; p = intermediate primary setae). Scale bars: 0.5 mm.

FIGURES 18–21 . Figures 18–20 .
Plectrocnemia brevis McLachlan 1871
, 5th instar larva: 18, abdominal segment IX, ventral (ip = innermost primary seta; op = outermost primary seta; p = intermediate primary setae); 19, abdominal segment IX, dorsal, posterolateral setal trio (is = inner secondary seta; os = outer secondary seta; p = primary seta); 20, head and prothorax, dorsal (dotted lines = half-trapezoidal pattern of spots on posterior frontoclypeus, about 85°). Figure 21. P. c.
conspersa (Curtis 1834)
, 5th instar larva, head, dorsal (dotted curved line = shallow arc pattern of spots on posterior frontoclypeus, about 85°). Scale bars: 0.5 mm.

FIGURES 22–24 . Figures 22–23 .
Plectrocnemia g.
geniculata McLachlan 1871
, 5th instar larva: 22, head, dorsal (dotted lines = half-trapezoidal pattern of spots on posterior frontoclypeus, about 100°); 23, labrum, dorsal. Figure 24. P. c.
conspersa (Curtis 1834)
, 5th instar larva, labrum, dorsal (arrow = posterior mark). Scale bars: 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Legs yellow to yellowish brown, with numerous secondary setae on coxae, trochanters, and femora; tibiae and tarsi with smaller numbers of setae ( Fig. 8 ). Foretarsi each distinctly more than half as long as its tibia ( Fig. 8 , double arrow). Femora, especially mid- and hind femora, each with long ventral setal fringe. Each tibia with two long, black, slender apical spurs (e.g., Fig. 10 , arrows), foretibia with additional subapical spur (not visible in Fig. 8 ). Tip of each tarsus with ventral, semicircular fringe of tiny setae. Tarsal claws long and slender, slightly curved, pointed, each with basal spur ( Figs. 8–10 ).

Anal prolegs very prominent, incorporating section of abdominal segment IX, and consisting of unsclerotized basal ( Fig. 14 so) and sclerotized apical sections ( Fig. 14 sc) with 143–158 and 49–57 setae, respectively. Anal claw obtuse-angled, inner margin without teeth ( Fig. 14 ).
